title: Evaluating and Enhancing Out-of-Domain Generalization of Task-Oriented Dialog Systems for Task Completion without Turn-level Dialog Annotations
author: Adib Mosharrof (University of Kentucky), Moghis Fereidouni (University of Kentucky), A.B. Siddique (University of Kentucky), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses task-oriented dialog systems which are highly relevant to human-computer interactions in audio applications. The proposed methods for enhancing task completion performance could inform similar approaches in audio generation tasks.
background: Task-oriented dialog systems focus on enabling users to complete specific tasks through natural language communication, helping with reservations, appointments, etc.
contribution: This paper introduces the ZeroToD framework to enhance out-of-domain performance in task-oriented dialog systems without reliance on annotated data, achieving improved task completion success rates.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing models require extensive turn-level annotations to train, limiting scalability and flexibility.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon prior methods by leveraging multi-task instruction fine-tuning and a schema augmentation mechanism, allowing the model to generalize better to unseen domains.

key_innovation: Utilizes schema augmentation to create variations of domain schemas, enabling the model to learn and generalize across different task contexts effectively.
real_world_impact: The findings suggest that models developed through this approach could be implemented in real-world applications, reducing costs and the need for extensive manual annotations.
limitations: The paper notes the substantial computational resources required for model training, particularly affecting practical deployment.

new_terms.ZeroToD: **ZeroToD** refers to a framework that enhances task-oriented dialog systems using zero-shot learning principles, enabling better generalization without manual annotations.
new_terms.schema augmentation: **Schema augmentation** involves enriching the training data by including various schema representations, thus improving the system's adaptability to different contexts.
